div.p: ANTONIO: Okay, so lets talk about what this research means.
RAY: The first takeaway from this research is that heredity establishes our level of biological risk for developing alcoholism.
ANTONIO: But, alcoholism isn't completely determined by our genetics?
RAY: That's correct. Some of us are biologically predisposed to developing alcoholism, but none of us are genetically predestined.
ANTONIO: So, just because I have an increased biological risk, doesn't mean that I'll definitely develop alcoholism.
RAY: That's absolutely right. If you think back to those who had a birth parent with alcoholism, they were four times more likely to develop alcoholism themselves, but not all of them did.
RAY: In fact, 80% of those with a family history of alcoholism did not develop it.
RAY: On the other hand, some who had no biological family history of alcoholism did develop it.
ANTONIO: So, clearly, they were not immune...
RAY: That's Right. What this research tells us is that all of us have some level of biological risk for developing alcoholism, some people have increased risk.
ANTONIO: Okay. Thanks, Ray. If you're still curious, there's been further research on twins and alcoholism that can tell us even more about inherited risk.
ANTONIO: Visit this link to the resources section if you'd like to find out more.
ANTONIO: So Ray, what about drug addiction?
RAY: Well, the original adoption research was done with just alcohol and alcoholism.
RAY: Later research has shown that those who have a birth parent with alcoholism are also four times more likely to experience serious problems with drugs.
RAY: And, even later research has gotten more specific, linking it to marijuana, to opiates such as morphine, to stimulants such as cocaine, and sedatives such as Valium.
ANTONIO: And what about people who didn't have a birth parent with alcoholism?
RAY: Well, while those who did have a family history were more likely to, still many people who develop drug addictions do not have any family history of either alcoholism or drug addiction.
ANTONIO: So, just like alcoholism, drug addiction can happen to anyone?
RAY: That's right. It can happen to anyone, some people have increased biological risk, and our family history can be a clue to our level of biological risk.
ANTONIO: Thanks, Ray.
